questions.text: : A construction worker met with an accident and presented to the trauma centre when a heavy concrete block fell over his face. He was found to have severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. He was not able to open his mouth, and on examination, he was found to have multiple fractures and obstruction in the patent airway. Which of the following would be the correct management strategy to restore the airway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case,emergency tracheostomyshould be done.

  • This patient has maxillofacial and laryngeal injury. In addition, he is unable to open his mouth. So, endotracheal intubation and cricothyroidotomy cannot be done.
  • Elective tracheostomy should not be done in emergencies.

Indications for emergency tracheostomy:

  • Acute upper airway obstruction with failed endotracheal intubation (foreign body, angioedema, infection, anaphylaxis, etc.)
  • Post-cricothyrotomy (if a cricothyrotomy has been placed, it should be immediately formalised into a tracheostomy once an airway has been secured)
  • Penetrating laryngeal trauma
  • LeFort III fracture

Explanation for other options:

Submental endotracheal intubation (Option A): Not suitable in emergencies or cases with facial trauma.

Cricothyroidotomy (Option C): Temporary emergency procedure, less preferred in laryngeal trauma due to the risk of further injury.

Elective tracheostomy (Option D): Not appropriate for immediate airway obstruction; used in planned, stable cases.

choices.text: Do suction of tube after putting normal saline in the tube

questions.text: : A 55-year-old woman has been suffering from COPD with neuromuscular respiratory insufficiency. 1 week back, she underwent tracheostomy for airway support and bronchial toilet. She is now in the ward. In the morning round, you find that the tracheostomy tube is blocked and her SpO2 is 72%. What immediate management will you carry out?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is an acute airway emergency. So, the tube should be removed immediately.

  • A blocked tracheostomy tube can completely obstruct ventilation, causing hypoxia.
  • The first and most effective step is to remove the tube immediately, especially if suctioning fails or isn’t possible.
  • After removal, either insert a new tracheostomy tube or provide bag-mask ventilation over the stoma or mouth, depending on the situation.

Explanation for other options:

  • Oxygen will not help the patient as the tube is already blocked. (Option A ruled out)
  • Deriphyllin is a bronchodilator. It has no role in the management of a blocked tube. (Option B ruled out)
  • Suction of the tube after putting in normal saline helps in clearing the crusts. This helps to prevent blockage of the tube. But it is not helpful after blockage has occurred. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A carcinoma larynx patient presents to emergency with stridor and respiratory difficulty. The Emergency medical officer has planned to do an urgent tracheostomy. What should be the best level of tracheostomy in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The best level of tracheostomy in this case is at the 1st and 2nd tracheal rings (High Tracheostomy)

High tracheostomy

  • Done above the level of the thyroid isthmus, at the level of the 1st and 2nd tracheal rings.
  • Side effects: Perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis
  • The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx; this is performed so that after a total laryngectomy, an adequate length of trachea remains to be sutured to the skin of the neck to create a permanent tracheostomy.

Mid tracheostomy

  • The most common site for tracheostomy (mid-tracheostomy) involves making a hole in the second and third tracheal rings and would entail division of the thyroid isthmus (lies against II, III, and IV tracheal rings) or its retraction upwards or downwards to expose this part of the trachea.
  • The first tracheal ring is usually left intact to prevent damage to the larynx.

Low tracheostomy

  • Low tracheostomy is less common and is performed at the third and fourth or fourth and fifth tracheal rings below the level of the isthmus.
  • The indication for low tracheostomy is tracheal stenosis in the upper part of the trachea (first and second tracheal rings) due to trauma.
  • The trachea is deep at this level and close to several large vessels, and the tracheostomy tube can impinge on the suprasternal notch.

Explanation for other options:

4th and 5th tracheal rings (Option A): Risks injury to the innominate artery or mediastinal structures.

3rd and 4th tracheal rings (Option B): Lower than ideal in carcinoma. May not preserve enough trachea for permanent tracheostomy.

2nd and 3rd tracheal rings (Option D): Standard in emergencies, but not sufficient in laryngeal carcinoma planned for laryngectomy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, while having dinner, suddenly becomes aphonic and is brought to the casualty with the complaint of respiratory difficulty. What should be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heimlich manoeuvre is the treatment of choice for Choking (Airway obstruction due to a foreign body)

Heimlich manoeuvre:

  • Heimlich manoeuvre is a sudden thrust directed upward and backwards below the epigastrium.
  • It squeezes the residual air from the lungs, which dislodges the foreign body. This manoeuvre should not be done if there is partial obstruction.
  • Cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy is done if the Heimlich manoeuvre fails.

Explanation for other options:

Intubation (Option A): Not effective if the foreign body is completely obstructing the airway.

Tracheostomy (Option B): Invasive and not first-line; reserved if Heimlich fails or in OR setting.

Humidified oxygen (Option C): Supportive only, not curative in complete obstruction.

choices.text: Total laryngectomy with post op radiotherapy

questions.text: The immediate treatment of T3 N0 M0 carcinoma larynx presenting with respiratory distress and stridor is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has respiratory distress and stridor. So, the answer here is tracheostomy as the airway is always the immediate concern. High tracheostomy is done in cancer larynx.

  • This is followed by total laryngectomy with post OP radiotherapy.
  • Partial laryngectomy with chemoradiation is done for T2 lesions.
  • Laser cordectomy is used for T1 lesions.

Indications for Tracheostomy:

  1. Respiratory obstruction
    • Infections
      1. Acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, acute epiglottitis, diphtheria
      2. Ludwig's angina, peritonsillar, retropharyngeal or parapharyngeal abscess, tongue abscess
    • Trauma
      1. External injury to the larynx and trachea
      2. Trauma due to endoscopies, especially in infants and children
      3. Fractures of the mandible or maxillofacial injuries
    • Neoplasms
    • Foreign body larynx
    • Oedema larynx due to:
      1. steam
      2. irritant fumes or gases
      3. allergy (angioneurotic or drug sensitivity)
      4. radiation
    • Bilateral abductor paralysis
    • Congenital anomalies
      1. Laryngeal web, cysts, tracheo-oesophageal fistula
    • Bilateral choanal atresia
  2. Retained secretions
    • Inability to cough
      1. Coma of any cause / Prolonged intubation (e.g. head injuries, cerebrovascular accidents, narcotic overdose)
      2. Paralysis of respiratory muscles (e.g. spinal injuries, polio, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis)
      3. Spasm of respiratory muscles (e.g. tetanus, eclampsia, strychnine poisoning)
    • Painful cough
    • Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
  3. Respiratory insufficiency
    • Chronic lung conditions: emphysema, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, atelectasis

Explanation for other options:

Total laryngectomy (Option A):  Definitive treatment, but not appropriate as an emergency step in a patient with airway compromise.

Partial laryngectomy with chemoradiation (Option B): Not an emergency airway measure.

Laser cordectomy (Option C): Suitable for early glottic lesions (T1-T2); not appropriate for T3 lesions or emergencies.

questions.text: Cricothyroidotomy is extremely effective in an emergency, and the patient can be ventilated for up to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cricothyroidotomy (Minitracheostomy or laryngotomy)

  • Cricothyroidotomy is a life-saving emergency airway procedure performed when intubation is not possible.
  • It allows rapid access to the airway through the cricothyroid membrane.
  • It is not intended for long-term ventilation due to complications like subglottic stenosis, perichondritis, and subglottic oedema..
  • The patient can be ventilated for up to 24 - 48 hours.

choices.text: Identifying the mobility of vocal cord
Identification of preservation of normal mucosal wave of vocal cord
Malignant lesions are seen in blue color

questions.text: Laryngeal videostroboscopy helps to differentiate benign from early malignant lesions of the vocal cord by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laryngeal videostroboscopy helps to differentiate benign from early malignant lesions of the vocal cord by identification of preservation of the normal mucosal wave of the vocal cord.

  • Mucosal waveis the pattern of light travelling mediolaterally along the superior surface of the vocal fold during vibration under illumination.
  • It is a correlate of the pliable cover (epithelium and superficial lamina propria) of the vocal fold being displaced relative to the body of the vocal fold (vocalis muscle).
  • Focal abnormalities of the mucosal wave help to localise pathology in the vocal fold.
  • This helps to differentiate benign from malignant lesions.

The following parameters can also be assessed using stroboscopy:

  1. Thefundamental speech frequencyof the patient
  2. Periodicity: It refers to the regularity of the successive vocal fold movements
  3. Symmetry: Normal vocal folds vibrate in a symmetric manner
  4. Glottic closure: During the normal vibratory phase, the membranous portion of the vocal cord firmly apposes, while the posterior glottic chink may be open.

Explanation for other options:

Identifying the mobility of the vocal cord (Option A): Mobility assessment is important in vocal cord evaluation, but can be done using flexible or rigid endoscopy. It doesn't distinguish between benign and malignant lesions specifically.

Visualising the lesion better (Option C): Standard laryngoscopy (flexible or rigid) provides good visualisation of lesions. Videostroboscopy may enhance dynamic visualisation during phonation, but is not primarily intended to'see' the lesion more clearly. Hence, this is not the main distinguishing mechanism for benign vs malignant lesions.

Malignant lesions are seen in blue colour (Option D): There is no such colour distinction in stroboscopy. Malignant lesions do not appear blue.

choices.text: Early vocal cord paralysis is common

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about supraglottic malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Supraglottic cancers do not typically cause early vocal cord paralysis as the cords are anatomically inferior to the lesion. Paralysis is seen later due to infiltration or nerve involvement.

Common Site:

  • The epiglottis is the most commonly involved site in supraglottic cancers.
  • Often, the initial site is before spreading to nearby supraglottic structures (e.g., aryepiglottic folds, false cords).

Nodal Metastasis:

  • Early lymphatic spread is a hallmark of supraglottic cancers.
  • Occurs in ~30% of cases.
  • Commonly involved nodes:
    • Level II (Upper deep cervical) (Option C ruled out)
    • Level III (Middle jugular)
  • Bilateral metastasis is common, especially with epiglottic involvement.

Voice Change:

  • Tumours of the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds cause:
    • Muffled, thick-sounding voice (like speaking with a hot potato in the mouth).
    • Due to the mass effect and changes in resonance. (Option A ruled out)

Referred Otalgia:

  • The supraglottic region shares sensory innervation with the external ear via the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold’s nerve).
  • Hence, referred ear pain (otalgia) is a frequent presenting symptom. (Option D ruled out)

Glottic cancer has got least chances of metastatic neck nodes as the vocal cords have no lymphatics.

questions.text: The Gold standard surgical procedure for the prevention of aspiration is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A permanent tracheostomy is created in laryngeal diversion procedures used to prevent aspiration.

  • The continuity between the laryngopharynx and the trachea is permanently disrupted, and the cut end of the trachea is sutured to the skin.
  • Permanent tracheostomy is needed for carcinoma larynx, laryngeal stenosis, and bilateral abductor paralysis.

Explanation for other options:

Thyroplasty (Option A): Primarily used for vocal cord paralysis or glottic insufficiency, not for aspiration prevention.

Tracheostomy (Option B): Helpful in airway management, but does not prevent aspiration unless tracheal division is added.

Feeding gastrostomy/jejunostomy (Option D): Avoids oral intake but does not prevent aspiration of saliva or secretions.

choices.text: The main issue with Fuller's tracheostomy tube is that the patient is unable to speak
The Chevalier Jackson tube is made of metal
Cuff of PVC tracheostomy tube should be high volume and low pressure
The tube should be removed immediately in case of obstruction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the tracheostomy tubes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fuller's tracheostomy tube has one advantage because of the fenestration of the inner tube and biflanged outer tube; there is a possibility of the patient speaking with the tracheostomy tube in situ.

Explanation for other options:

Chevalier Jackson tube (Option B): They are typically made of metal, which allows for sterilisation and reuse, potentially reducing costs and infection risks compared to disposable plastic tubes.

PVC (plastic) tracheostomy tubes (Option C): These are usually cuffed, and the cuff should ideally be high volume and low pressure to prevent tracheal mucosal injury.

If a tracheostomy tube is obstructed and cannot be cleared, it should be removed immediately to establish a patent airway and prevent hypoxia. (Option D)

choices.text: High tracheostomy is done in cancer larynx patients
The tracheostomy tube should be removed immediately if blocked
Low volume high pressure cuff tubes are better as they prevent tracheomalacia

questions.text: All of the following are true about tracheostomy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-volume and low-pressure cuff of a tracheostomy tube is better, as this will prevent tracheomalacia. This also prevents ischemia and cartilage necrosis.
  • Low-volume high-pressure cuffs exert a focal, high pressure on the tracheal wall, increasing the risk of tracheal injury, ischemia, and even tracheomalacia.

Explanation for other options:

High tracheostomy (Option A) is sometimes performed in laryngeal cancer patients, especially when the tumour involves the lower parts of the larynx or for airway protection during surgery.

Decannulation (removal of tracheostomy tube) (Option B) is often more difficult in children due to smaller airways, higher risk of airway collapse, and greater dependence on the tube.

If a tracheostomy tube becomes blocked (Option C), especially with secretions or a blood clot, it must be removed immediately to restore a patent airway and avoid hypoxia.

choices.text: High tracheostomy may lead to subglottic stenosis
Anterior Jugular veins and inferior thyroid veins are the most common site of bleeding
In pediatric tracheostomy, a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall is removed
Percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy is used mostly in ICU patients

questions.text: All of the following are true about tracheostomy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pediatric tracheostomy, we don't remove the circular ring of the anterior tracheal wall because this can lead to tracheomalacia later on.

  • In adults, we remove a circular ring of the anterior tracheal wall to place the tube.
  • High tracheostomy involves the first tracheal ring and causes perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis. (Option A ruled out) It is only done in a case of cancer larynx.
  • Anterior Jugular veins and inferior thyroid veins are the most common sites of bleeding, as these superficial veins are commonly encountered and injured during dissection, especially if not adequately ligated. (Option B ruled out)
  • Haemorrhage is the most common intraoperative complication in tracheostomy.
  • Percutaneous tracheostomy is minimally invasive and widely used in ICU settings for patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is typically done bedside under sedation, using the Seldinger technique.

Complications of Tracheostomy

Immediate Complications:

  • Haemorrhage-Most common; from anterior jugular or thyroid vessels.
  • Surgical emphysema- Due to air leak; worsened by tight skin sutures.
  • Apnea CO2 washout reduces respiratory drive temporarily.
  • Pneumothorax-Rare; more common in children due to high pleural apex.
  • Loss of voice-Due to bypassing the vocal cords.

Late Complications:

  • Infection-At the tracheostomy site, if hygiene is poor.
  • Subglottic stenosis-From trauma, infection, or prolonged tracheostomy.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be seen on indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior commissure of the vocal cords is not seen on indirect laryngoscopy.

  • Indirect Laryngoscopy is done using a pre-warmed indirect laryngoscopy mirror.
  • Pre-warming prevents fogging of the mirror.

Structuresnot visible on indirect laryngoscopyinclude-

  • Anterior commissure of vocal cords
  • Laryngeal surface of the epiglottis
  • Undersurface of vocal cords
  • The adjoining area of the Subglottis
  • Apex of the pyriform fossa
  • Ventricle and saccule

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy

Oropharynx

  • Base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds

Laryngopharynx

  • Pyriform fossae
  • Post cricoid region
  • Posterior wall

Larynx

  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords
  • Tracheal rings

questions.text: Which structure is not removed in Radical Neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radical neck dissection is done to clear the secondary neck nodes in a case of metastatic head and neck cancer. The digastric muscle is not removed in this surgery.

Structures Removed:

  • LN (Lymph nodes) level I–V
  • SCM (Sternocleidomastoid muscle) (Option B ruled out)
  • Spinal accessory nerve (SAN) (Option D ruled out)
  • IJV (Internal Jugular Vein) (Option A ruled out)
  • Tail of the parotid
  • Submandibular gland
  • Omohyoid

Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND)
Removal of lymphatic tissues in levels I to V with preservation of one or more non-lymphatic structures:

  • Type I: Preservation of SAN
  • Type II: Preservation of IJV, SAN
  • Type III: Preservation of SCM, IJV, SAN

Flashes of light are synchronised to vocal cord vibration
Does not assess the mucosal wave form of the vocal cord on phonation
A very useful investigation in patients with voice disorders

questions.text: Which of the following does not apply to Videostroboscopy of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Videostroboscopy helps to assess the mucosal wave form of the vocal cord during phonation.

Stroboscopy

  • Stroboscopy is a special method used to visualise vocal fold vibration.
  • It uses a synchronised (Option B ruled out), flashing light passed through a flexible or rigid telescope. (Option A ruled out)
  • It is a very useful investigation in patients with voice disorders. (Option D ruled out)

Characteristics of Vocal Folds (VF) that are to be seen are:

  • VF closure (pattern and duration)
  • Mucosal wave movement (propagation)
  • Symmetry of vibration
  • Amplitude of VF vibration
  • Periodicity

questions.text: The Gold standard test for laryngopharyngeal reflux is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease (LPRD) is best diagnosed with 24-hour double-probe pH monitoring.

It has two probes.

  • Distal probe→ 5cm above the lower oesophageal sphincter
  • Proximal probe → 1cm above the upper oesophageal sphincter, in the hypopharynx behind the laryngeal inlet.

Diagnosis:

  • In LPRD - Acidic pH in both probes
  • In GERD(Gastroesophageal reflux disease) - Acidic pH in distal probe only.

Explanation for other options:

Oesophageal motility study (Option A): This test evaluates the muscular contractions of the oesophagus (peristalsis) and lower oesophageal sphincter function. It is used primarily for oesophageal motility disorders such as achalasia and not for diagnosing reflux, especially laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR).

Barium swallow (Option B): This is a radiographic study used to assess the anatomy of the upper GI tract and detect structural abnormalities like strictures or masses. It cannot accurately detect acid reflux episodes, especially those reaching the laryngopharynx, and hence is not reliable for LPR diagnosis.

Oesophageal biopsy (Option D): While this can detect esophagitis or Barrett's oesophagus, it is not diagnostic for reflux, especially not for LPR. It also does not measure the frequency, duration, or pH of reflux events.
